item.title: Optimal mutual insurance against systematic longevity risk
item.description: arXiv:2410.07749v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: We mathematically demonstrate how and what it means for two collective pension funds to mutually insure one another against systematic longevity risk. The key equation that facilitates the exchange of insurance is a market clearing condition. This enables an insurance market to be established even if the two funds face the same mortality risk, so long as they have different risk preferences. Provided the preferences of the two funds are not too dissimilar, insurance provides little benefit, implying the base scheme is effectively optimal. When preferences vary significantly, insurance can be beneficial.
item.dc:creator: John Armstrong, James Dalby

item.title: Computing Systemic Risk Measures with Graph Neural Networks
item.description: arXiv:2410.07222v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: This paper investigates systemic risk measures for stochastic financial networks of explicitly modelled bilateral liabilities. We extend the notion of systemic risk measures from Biagini, Fouque, Fritelli and Meyer-Brandis (2019) to graph structured data. In particular, we focus on an aggregation function that is derived from a market clearing algorithm proposed by Eisenberg and Noe (2001). In this setting, we show the existence of an optimal random allocation that distributes the overall minimal bailout capital and secures the network. We study numerical methods for the approximation of systemic risk and optimal random allocations. We propose to use permutation equivariant architectures of neural networks like graph neural networks (GNNs) and a class that we name (extended) permutation equivariant neural networks ((X)PENNs). We compare their performance to several benchmark allocations. The main feature of GNNs and (X)PENNs is that they are permutation equivariant with respect to the underlying graph data. In numerical experiments we find evidence that these permutation equivariant methods are superior to other approaches.
item.dc:creator: Lukas Gonon, Thilo Meyer-Brandis, Niklas Weber

item.title: Optimal hedging with variational preferences under convex risk measures
item.description: arXiv:2407.03431v2 Announce Type: replace Abstract: We expose a theoretical hedging optimization framework with variational preferences under convex risk measures. We explore a general dual representation for the composition between risk measures and utilities. We study the properties of the optimization problem as a convex and monotone map per se. We also derive results for optimality and indifference pricing conditions. We also explore particular examples inside our setup.
